conclusion: To determine the moment when the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the given velocity-time graph for both objects A and B.
The distance between the two objects at any time t can be found by integrating the difference in their velocities from t = 0 to t.
From t = 0 to t = t1, object A has a positive velocity while object B has a decreasing velocity.
From t = t1 to t = t2, object A continues with a constant velocity v0 while object B's velocity increases.
From t = t2 to t = t3, object A's velocity decreases linearly to zero while object B's velocity continues to increase.
From t = t3 to t = t4, object A remains stationary while object B's velocity continues to increase.

premise: The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of each object.
conclusion: The difference in these areas gives the separation between the two objects.

premise: At t = t1, object A has moved some distance while object B has moved less due to its decreasing velocity.
conclusion: Object A is ahead of object B at t = t1.

premise: At t = t2, object A has moved further with a constant velocity v0 while object B has increased its velocity but still lags behind.
conclusion: Object A is still ahead of object B at t = t2.

premise: At t = t3, object A's velocity decreases to zero, but it has accumulated more distance than object B, which is still increasing its velocity.
conclusion: Object A is farthest ahead of object B at t = t3.

premise: At t = t4, object A remains stationary while object B continues to increase its velocity.
conclusion: Object B starts to catch up with object A after t = t3.

premise: The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the velocity-time graphs is the greatest.
conclusion: This happens at t = t3 because after this point, object B starts to catch up with object A.
